revision.text:
{{Infobox Radar |name = AN/APG-77 |image = APG-77-1A.jpg |caption = AN/APG-77 |country = [[United States]] |introdate = |number = |type = [[Solid state (electronics)|Solid-state]] [[Active electronically scanned array|active electronically scanned array (AESA)]] |frequency = |range = |altitude = |diameter = |azimuth = 120° |elevation = |precision = |power = 20 kW peak{{Citation needed|date=April 2008}} }}
The '''AN/APG-77''' is a multifunction [[Low probability of intercept radar]] installed on the [[F-22 Raptor]] fighter aircraft. The radar is built by [[Northrop Grumman]].
It is a [[Solid state (electronics)|solid-state]], [[active electronically scanned array]] (AESA) radar. Composed of 1956 [[Transceiver|transmit/receive modules]],<ref>http://www.f-16.net/forum/viewtopic.php?f=22&t=24978&p=267267</ref><ref>[http://www.acq.osd.mil/dsb/reports/hfradar.pdf Hfradar.pdf page 19 for number of modules] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060422102714/http://www.acq.osd.mil/dsb/reports/hfradar.pdf |date=April 22, 2006 }}</ref><ref>http://www.acq.osd.mil/dsb/reports/ADA391893.pdf</ref> each about the size of a gum stick, it can perform a near-instantaneous [[beam steering]] (in the order of tens of [[nanosecond]]s).
[[File:AN-APG-77, AESA, Active Electronically Scanned Array, Northrop Grumman, 2001 - National Electronics Museum - DSC00388.jpg|thumb|left|AN/APG-77 in the [[National Electronics Museum]].]]
The APG-77 provides 120° [[field of view]] in azimuth and elevation,{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} which is the highest possible value for a flat [[phased array]] antenna.<ref>[http://www.radartutorial.eu/06.antennas/an14.en.html Physical limitation of the maximum swivel angle of an AESA]</ref> Unconfirmed sources suggest that APG-77 has an operating range of {{convert|125|-|150|mi|km|abbr=on}},<ref>http://www.webcitation.org/6Qpsm5PUo?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.f22-raptor.com%2Fmedia%2Fdocuments%2Faviation_week_010807.pdf</ref> against a {{convert|1|m2|sqft|abbr=on}} target. A range of 400 km, against a {{convert|1|m2|sqft|abbr=on}} target, with the APG-77v1, with newer [[Gallium arsenide|GaAs]] modules, is believed to be possible with the use of more narrow beams.<ref>http://www.f-16.net/forum/viewtopic.php?f=22&t=24978&p=267267</ref><ref>http://www.webcitation.org/6Qpsm5PUo?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.f22-raptor.com%2Fmedia%2Fdocuments%2Faviation_week_010807.pdf</ref><ref>http://www.f-16.net/forum/viewtopic.php?f=33&t=25728</ref>
More than one hundred APG-77 AESA radars have been produced to date by Northrop Grumman, and much of the technology developed for the APG-77 is being used in the [[APG-81]] radar for the [[F-35 Lightning II]].
The APG-77v1 was installed on [[F-22]] Raptors from Lot 5 and on.<ref>https://defense-update.com/newscast/0407/news_020407.htm#raptor</ref> This provided full air-to-ground functionality (high-resolution [[synthetic aperture radar]] mapping, [[ground moving target indication]] and track (GMTI/GMTT), automatic cueing and recognition, combat identification, and many other advanced features).<ref>https://www.forecastinternational.com/archive/disp_pdf.cfm?DACH_RECNO=942</ref><ref>https://defense-update.com/newscast/0407/news_020407.htm#raptor</ref>
